data.title: AMC y SIP condenan ataques de las Fuerzas Armadas a la prensa en Honduras
data.description: La Asociación de Medios de Comunicación de Honduras (AMC) y la Sociedad Interamericana de Prensa (SIP) condenaron enérgicamente los ataques de las Fuerzas Armadas y la Secretaría de Defensa contra periodistas, a quienes han señalado públicamente como enemigos del Estado. El episodio ha sido calificado como una escalada sin precedentes en la intimidación sistemática contra la libertad de expresión y de prensa en Honduras. “Han pasado de ser una amenaza velada a la libertad de expresión, a convertirse en una amenaza a la integridad de los periodistas desde la estructura del Estado, algo que ni siquiera se vio en la Guerra Fría”, advierte la AMC. La AMC lamentó que sean precisamente las Fuerzas Armadas y la Secretaría de Defensa, instituciones que ostentan poder delegado por el pueblo hondureño, las que se alcen contra la libertad de expresión, poniendo en peligro las vidas de periodistas que ejercen un periodismo independiente, responsable y serio, “siendo baluartes en la defensa de la democracia”. “La actitud tanto de las FF AA como de la Secretaría de Defensa no compagina con la tolerancia que están obligadas a guardar ambas por la Ley, al régimen de opinión pública, cuya labor está establecida en la Carta de las Naciones Unidas, la Declaración Universal de los Derechos Humanos, la Convención Americana sobre Derechos Humanos, el Pacto de San José, la Declaración de Chapultepec y la Ley de Emisión del Pensamiento en Honduras como derecho y obligación de los medios de comunicación, para garantizar las libertades de la sociedad”, condenó la AMC. Asimismo, exhortó “con urgencia la protección inmediata de los periodistas Rodrigo Wong Arévalo, Dagoberto Rodríguez Coello y Juan Carlos Sierra, quienes han quedado expuestos a sufrir cualquier tipo de atentado que ponga en riesgo su vida”. La organización también reprochó “la actitud totalmente antidemocrática de las FF AA y la Secretaría de Defensa”, y pidió a las instituciones del Estado, organismos internacionales y a la comunidad internacional que intercedan “para proteger la libertad de expresión en Honduras y la vida de los tres periodistas”. La AMC responsabilizó a ambas instituciones “por los daños que pudieran sufrir nuestros afiliados”. La denuncia se produce tras la publicación del 26 de mayo en el medio oficial FF AA Digital, bajo el título “Sicarios de la verdad” , donde se presentó en portada un artículo acompañado de fotografías de tres reconocidos periodistas: Rodrigo Wong Arévalo, director del programa Abriendo Brecha y propietario de Canal 10; Dagoberto Rodríguez, director de Radio Cadena Voces y Premio Álvaro Contreras 2025; y Juan Carlos Sierra, presidente del Colegio de Periodistas de Honduras (CPH). En la publicación, los comunicadores fueron acusados de ser “enemigos del Estado”, sin ofrecer pruebas, en lo que la SIP calificó como “una clara campaña de desprestigio, intimidación y criminalización del ejercicio periodístico”. Este ataque habría surgido tras declaraciones críticas de Dagoberto Rodríguez durante la ceremonia del Premio Álvaro Contreras, en la que denunció irregularidades atribuidas a las Fuerzas Armadas durante las elecciones internas del 9 de marzo, como “la entrega tardía de maletas electorales en centros de Tegucigalpa y San Pedro Sula”. La SIP también expresó su más enérgico repudio a esta ofensiva contra medios y periodistas. José Roberto Dutriz, presidente de la SIP y director de La Prensa Gráfica de El Salvador, afirmó que “el acoso judicial y la estigmatización pública se han convertido en armas sistemáticas para intentar silenciar al periodismo, especialmente cuando se exponen actos de corrupción y abuso de poder”. Martha Ramos, directora editorial de la Organización Editorial Mexicana (OEM) y presidenta de la Comisión de Libertad de Prensa e Información de la SIP, advirtió que “no se trata solo de un agravio a tres periodistas, sino de un mensaje peligroso para toda la prensa crítica del país”. “Cuando las Fuerzas Armadas utilizan su aparato de comunicación para amedrentar, están sobrepasando los límites que deben respetar en una democracia. Ese tipo de conducta no puede normalizarse”, declaró. La SIP recordó también que, en febrero pasado, el alto mando militar impulsó acciones judiciales contra 12 medios de comunicación para obligarlos a revelar sus fuentes, lo que fue calificado como una grave violación de los principios periodísticos y del derecho internacional. El Colegio de Periodistas de Honduras (CPH) condenó enérgicamente la publicación y responsabilizó al jefe del Estado Mayor Conjunto, Roosevelt Hernández, y a la hasta ayer ministra de Defensa, Rixi Moncada, por cualquier atentado, hostigamiento o daño que puedan sufrir los periodistas mencionados. El Comisionado Nacional de los Derechos Humanos (Conadeh) también se pronunció, recordando al Estado su deber de proteger la libertad de pensamiento y expresión. “La libertad de expresión protege incluso aquello que incomoda a autoridades o sectores sociales, especialmente cuando se trata de temas de interés público”, indicó la Corte Interamericana de Derechos Humanos, citada por el Conadeh. Blanca Izaguirre, titular del organismo, subrayó que “la libertad de expresión es un pilar esencial del Estado de derecho, especialmente cuando se ejerce como veeduría social ante actos de la administración pública”. El Conadeh exhortó a la institucionalidad a abstenerse de emitir pronunciamientos que intimiden, directa o indirectamente, a periodistas y medios de comunicación.
data.translatedTitle: AMC and SIP condemn attacks from armed forces to the press in Honduras
data.translatedDescription: The Association of Media of Honduras (AMC) and the Inter -American Press Society (SIP) strongly condemned the attacks of the Armed Forces and the Secretariat of Defense against Journalists, whom they have publicly pointed out as enemies of the State. The episode has been qualified as an unprecedented escalation in systematic intimidation against freedom of expression and press in Honduras. "They have gone from being a veiled threat to freedom of expression, to become a threat to the integrity of journalists from the structure of the State, something that was not even seen in the cold war," warns the AMC. The AMC regretted that they are precisely the Armed Forces and the Secretariat of Defense, institutions that hold power delegated by the Honduran people, which are raised against freedom of expression, endangering the lives of journalists who exercise independent, responsible and serious journalism, "being bastions in the defense of democracy." “The attitude of both the FF AA and the Ministry of Defense does not compare guarantee the freedoms of society, ”said the AMC. He also urgently urged the immediate protection of journalists Rodrigo Wong Arévalo, Dagoberto Rodríguez Coello and Juan Carlos Sierra, who have been exposed to suffer any type of attack that puts their lives at risk. " The organization also reproached "the totally antidemocratic attitude of the FF AA and the Secretariat of Defense," and asked the State institutions, international organizations and the international community to intercede "to protect freedom of expression in Honduras and the life of the three journalists." The AMC responsible for both institutions "for the damages that our affiliates could suffer." The complaint occurs after the publication of May 26 in the official FF AA Digital, under the title “Sicarios de la Truth”, where an article accompanied by photographs of three renowned journalists was presented on the cover: Rodrigo Wong Arévalo, director of the program opening the gap and owner of Channel 10; Dagoberto Rodríguez, director of Radio Cadena Voces and Álvaro Contreras 2025; and Juan Carlos Sierra, president of the College of Journalists of Honduras (CPH). In the publication, the communicators were accused of being "enemies of the State", without offering evidence, in what the SIP described as "a clear campaign of discredit, intimidation and criminalization of the journalistic exercise." This attack would have emerged after critical statements by Dagoberto Rodríguez during the Álvaro Contreras Prize ceremony, in which he denounced irregularities attributed to the Armed Forces during the internal elections of March 9, such as “the late delivery of electoral suitcases in Centers of Tegucigalpa and San Pedro Sula”. The SIP also expressed its most energetic repudiation of this offensive against media and journalists. José Roberto Dutriz, president of the SIP and director of the graphic press of El Salvador, said that "judicial harassment and public stigmatization have become systematic weapons to try to silence journalism, especially when acts of corruption and abuse of power are exposed." Martha Ramos, editorial director of the Mexican Editorial Organization (OEM) and president of the SIP Press and Information Commission, warned that "it is not just a grievance to three journalists, but a dangerous message for the entire critical press of the country." "When the Armed Forces use their communication apparatus to intimidate, they are exceeding the limits they must respect in a democracy. That type of behavior cannot be normalized," he said. The SIP also recalled that, last February, the Military High Command promoted judicial actions against 12 media to force them to reveal their sources, which was qualified as a serious violation of journalistic principles and international law. The College of Journalists of Honduras (CPH) strongly condemned the publication and responsible for the Chief of the Joint Chief, Roosevelt Hernández, and until yesterday Minister of Defense, Rixi Moncada, for any attack, harassment or damage that the aforementioned journalists may suffer. The National Human Rights Commissioner (Conadeh) also pronounced, reminding the State of its duty to protect freedom of thought and expression. "Freedom of expression even protects what bothers authorities or social sectors, especially when it comes to issues of public interest," said the Inter -American Court of Human Rights, cited by Conadeh. Blanca Izaguirre, head of the agency, stressed that "freedom of expression is an essential pillar of the rule of law, especially when exercised as social veeduría before acts of public administration." Conadeh urged institutionality to refrain from issuing pronouncements that intimidate, directly or indirectly, journalists and media.

data.title: Habitantes de campos bananeros exigen reparación de los bordos
data.description: Habitantes de los campos bananeros de La Lima, Cortés , bloquearon por varias horas la carretera que conduce a El Progreso para exigirle al gobierno la reparación de varios kilómetros de bordos de contención. A la altura de la colonia San José, los manifestantes incendiaron llantas y evitaron que los automóviles hasta que elementos de la Policía Nacional llegaron a desalojarlos bajo una lluvia de piedras que les lanzaron. Armando Velásquez, alcalde auxiliar de Corosalito, líder de la manifestación, dijo ante los medios de comunicación que “los bordos quedarán dañados desde las lluvias Eta y Iota” que afectaron el país en 2020. De acuerdo con explicaciones de Velásquez, los bordos, construidos en las orillas del canal Maya y río Chamelecón , presentan aberturas considerables por las cuales podría filtrarse el agua durante la temporada de lluvias. “Desde la carretera, el bordo se ve bonito, pero está deteriorado (...). Por el lado de las fincas bananeras hay unos 30 boquetes, hay oros frente a la colonia Las Metálicas y hay otros por la finca Omonita”, dijo. Otros habitantes del sector, como José Mariel, le solicitan al gobierno “dejar las mentiras a un lado y ponerse a trabajar de manera inmediata antes de que comiencen las lluvias que provocan inundaciones”. Delmis Cardona, jefe de la Unidad Municipal de Riesgo, le informó a los limeños a través Facebook que constaron que hay daños en los bordos que corresponden a este municipio. “Hay un área de la Lima que ya habíamos denunciado ante la SIT, Centro de Estudios y Desarrollo del Valle de Sula y el señor alcalde había hecho las gestiones para la reparación”, dijo. Propietarios de terrenos aledaños donarán material que será utilizado para hacer reparaciones, según autoridades locales.
data.translatedTitle: Inhabitants of banana fields demand repair of embroiders
data.translatedDescription: Inhabitants of the banana fields of the Lima, Cortés, blocked for several hours the road that leads to El Progreso to demand from the Government the repair of several kilometers of containment boards. At the height of the San José neighborhood, the protesters set fire to tires and prevented cars until elements of the National Police came to evict them under a rain of stones that threw them. Armando Velásquez, auxiliary mayor of Corosalito, leader of the demonstration, said before the media that “the embroiders will be damaged from the ETA and Iota rains” that affected the country in 2020. According to Velásquez's explanations, the embroiders, built on the banks of the Maya Canal and Chamelecón River, have considerable openings through which the water could be filtered during the rainy season. "From the road, the board looks beautiful, but it is deteriorated (...). On the side of the banana farms there are about 30 boquets, there are golds in front of the Las Metal neighborhood and there are others by the omonite farm," he said. Other inhabitants of the sector, such as José Mariel, ask the government to "leave lies aside and get to work immediately before the rains that cause floods begin." Delmis Cardona, head of the Municipal Risk Unit, informed the Lima through Facebook that they stated that there are damage to the boards that correspond to this municipality. "There is an area of ​​the Lima that we had already denounced before the SIT, Center for Studies and Development of the Sula Valley and Mr. Mayor had made the efforts for repair," he said. Owners of surrounding land will donate material that will be used to make repairs, according to local authorities.

data.title: Tres nombres suenan para sustituir a Rixi Moncada y Enrique Reina
data.description: Los nombres de Lesly Sarahí Cerna, Javier Efraín Bu Soto y Dessiré Flores Dubón se manejan en Casa Presidencial como posibles reemplazos de los tres funcionarios de confianza de la presidenta Xiomara Castro que renunciaron a sus cargos para dedicarse a la campaña electoral. Las salidas de Rixi Moncada (Defensa), Eduardo Enrique Reina (Cancillería) y Angélica Álvarez (Derechos Humanos) fueron formalizadas en cumplimiento de la Ley Electoral, que exige a los aspirantes a cargos de elección popular dejar sus funciones seis meses antes de los comicios generales, previstos para el 30 de noviembre. Aunque no hay anuncios oficiales, fuentes del Ejecutivo confirmaron a LA PRENSA que entre miércoles y jueves se oficializarán los nombramientos. Lesly Sarahí Cerna, abogada originaria de Catacamas, Olancho, ha ganado terreno en el círculo más cercano del poder. Su cercanía con la familia presidencial y su rol como operadora política de confianza la perfilan como posible sucesora en la Secretaría de Defensa, tras la salida de Rixi Moncada. Desde el 1 de julio de 2024, Cerna ocupa el cargo de ministra de la Presidencia, posición desde la cual coordina el gabinete y ejerce influencia directa en la agenda del Ejecutivo. Su ascenso fue inmediato tras la salida de Rodolfo Pastor de María y Campos. Formada en la Universidad Católica de Honduras (Unicah), con una maestría en Derecho Empresarial por Unitec y doctorado en Derecho Tributario por la Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala, Cerna inició su trayectoria de alto perfil el 27 de enero de 2022 como secretaria de Trabajo y Seguridad Social. Desde esa posición impulsó una narrativa centrada en los derechos laborales, aunque sin lograr reformas estructurales destacables. En septiembre de 2023, asumió la presidencia del Consejo Económico y Social (CES), desde donde intentó revitalizar el diálogo tripartito entre empleadores, trabajadores y Gobierno, sin mayor impacto sustantivo. Su ambición política quedó evidenciada en junio de 2023 al postularse para fiscal general. Sin embargo, su candidatura fue retirada por no cumplir con la edad mínima ni con experiencia penal, según los criterios legales. El 14 de junio de 2024, la presidenta Xiomara Castro la nombró ministra de la Presidencia, cargo desde el cual se ha desempeñado como brazo ejecutor del Ejecutivo. Su eventual traslado a Defensa supondría una mayor concentración de poder en una figura clave del círculo íntimo de la mandataria. Javier Efraín Bu Soto ha desarrollado una carrera diplomática de bajo perfil, pero con conexiones sólidas en las esferas del poder. Con más de 15 años residiendo en Estados Unidos, Bu ha sabido navegar los espacios de influencia de Washington, gracias a su formación académica y a su pertenencia a una familia con tradición política. A sus 42 años, nació en Tegucigalpa en el seno de una familia con historia en el servicio exterior: su madre fue cónsul en Galveston, Texas, y su abuelo presidió el Congreso Nacional. Su nombre figura como posible sustituto de Eduardo Enrique Reina en la Cancillería. Bu asumió como embajador en EE. UU. en enero de 2023, tras entregar credenciales al presidente Joe Biden. Previamente, desde febrero de 2022, se desempeñó como encargado de negocios en la misma sede diplomática. Su primer acercamiento al servicio exterior se remonta a 2009, cuando fue designado agregado legal en la embajada, en plena crisis tras el golpe de Estado contra Manuel Zelaya. En lo académico, posee doble maestría en Derecho y Gobierno, y Derecho Comercial Internacional por la American University, así como un doctorado en Jurisprudencia por Unitec. Antes de ocupar el rol de embajador, trabajó en el sector privado como director gerente de Group BG, firma vinculada a seguros en Washington, y brevemente como asistente legal en la Corte Suprema de Justicia y el Instituto de la Propiedad, en proyectos financiados por el Banco Mundial. Desde su llegada a la embajada, ha promovido la apertura de consulados en Pittsburgh, Phoenix y Tampa, además de la implementación de consulados móviles. Aunque visibles, estas gestiones han sido más logísticas que estratégicas, en un contexto de desafíos migratorios, diplomáticos y comerciales. Bu también ha sido interlocutor en temas como la renovación del TPS, migración y atracción de inversión, aunque sin protagonismo en negociaciones de alto nivel. Dessiré Flores Dubón es una figura conocida en los círculos de poder, más por su herencia política que por una trayectoria consolidada. Hija de Sonia Marlina Dubón Villeda, magistrada de la Corte Suprema de Justicia, y de Enrique Flores Lanza, exsecretario de la Presidencia durante el gobierno de Manuel Zelaya, actualmente asesora a la Presidencia, Dessiré ocupa hoy la Subsecretaría de la Presidencia y es miembro suplente del Consejo Nacional de Inversiones (CNI). Su nombre suena para reemplazar a Lesly Cerna en la Secretaría de la Presidencia, en caso de que esta última sea trasladada a Defensa. Su ascenso se explica más por los vínculos familiares que por una carrera independiente en lo político o técnico. El 15 de mayo de 2024 fue electa presidenta del Tribunal de Honor del Colegio de Abogados de Honduras (CAH), en una sesión polémica respaldada por los frentes Reivindicador, Gremialista y Patria y Justicia. Sin embargo, su nombramiento fue impugnado por Ana Cardona Herrera, quien alegó haber sido electa previamente en marzo por mayoría de los agremiados. Este episodio expuso tensiones dentro del gremio y cuestionamientos sobre la transparencia en la conformación de liderazgos. Flores Dubón representa una continuidad del proyecto político de Libre en distintas instancias estatales. Su eventual llegada a la Secretaría de la Presidencia implicaría asumir la coordinación del gabinete, el enlace con el Congreso y un rol central en la definición de la agenda del Ejecutivo. ETIQUETA DE TRANSPARENCIA: Este artículo fue revisado y aprobado por un editor con ayuda de una herramienta de inteligencia artificial.
data.translatedTitle: Three names sound to replace Rixi Moncada and Enrique Reina
data.translatedDescription: The names of Lesly Sarahí Cerna, Javier Efraín Bu Soto and Dessiré Flores Dubón are handled at the presidential house as possible replacements of the three trusted officials of President Xiomara Castro who renounced their positions to devote themselves to the electoral campaign. The departures of Rixi Moncada (Defense), Eduardo Enrique Reina (Foreign Ministry) and Angélica Álvarez (Human Rights) were formalized in compliance with the Electoral Law, which requires applicants for positions of popular election to leave their functions six months before the general elections, provided for November 30. Although there are no official ads, executive sources confirmed to the press that the appointments will be formalized between Wednesday and Thursday. Lesly Sarahí Cerna, a lawyer from Catacamas, Olancho, has gained ground in the closest circle of power. Her closeness with the presidential family and her role as a trusted political operator is emerging as a possible successor in the Secretariat of Defense, after the departure of Rixi Moncada. Since July 1, 2024, Cerna occupies the position of Minister of the Presidency, a position from which he coordinates the cabinet and exerts direct influence on the executive agenda. His ascent was immediate after the departure of Rodolfo Pastor de María and Campos. Trained at the Catholic University of Honduras (UNICAH), with a Master in Business Law by UNITEC and a PhD in Tax Law from the University of San Carlos de Guatemala, CERNA began its high -profile career on January 27, 2022 as Secretary of Labor and Social Security. From that position it promoted a narrative focused on labor rights, although without achieving remarkable structural reforms. In September 2023, he assumed the presidency of the Economic and Social Council (CES), from where he tried to revitalize the tripartite dialogue between employers, workers and government, without greater substantive impact. His political ambition was evidenced in June 2023 when he was running for the Attorney General. However, his candidacy was withdrawn for not fulfilling the minimum age or with criminal experience, according to legal criteria. On June 14, 2024, President Xiomara Castro appointed her Minister of the Presidency, a position from which she has served as an executive arm. His eventual transfer to Defense would mean a greater concentration of power in a key figure of the intimate circle of the president. Javier Efraín Bu Soto has developed a low profile diplomatic career, but with solid connections in the spheres of power. With more than 15 years residing in the United States, BU has managed to navigate the spaces of influence of Washington, thanks to his academic training and his belonging to a family with political tradition. At 42, he was born in Tegucigalpa within a family with history in the foreign service: his mother was consul in Galveston, Texas, and his grandfather presided over the National Congress. His name appears as a possible substitute for Eduardo Enrique Reina in the Foreign Ministry. BU assumed as an ambassador to the US. In January 2023, after giving credentials to President Joe Biden. Previously, since February 2022, he served as a business manager at the same diplomatic headquarters. His first approach to the foreign service dates back to 2009, when he was appointed legal aggregate at the embassy, ​​in full crisis after the coup against Manuel Zelaya. In academics, he has double mastery in law and government, and international commercial law from the American University, as well as a doctorate in jurisprudence for UNITEC. Before occupying the role of ambassador, he worked in the private sector as managing director of Group BG, a firm linked to insurance in Washington, and briefly as a legal assistant in the Supreme Court of Justice and the Institute of Property, in projects financed by the World Bank. Since its arrival at the Embassy, ​​it has promoted the opening of consulates in Pittsburgh, Phoenix and Tampa, in addition to the implementation of mobile consulates. Although visible, these efforts have been more logistical than strategic, in a context of migratory, diplomatic and commercial challenges. BU has also been an interlocutor on issues such as the renewal of TPS, migration and investment attraction, although without prominence in high -level negotiations. I will desss Flores Dubón is a figure known in the circles of power, more for its political inheritance than by a consolidated trajectory. Daughter of Sonia Marlina Dubón Villeda, magistrate of the Supreme Court of Justice, and Enrique Flores Lanza, former secretary of the Presidency during the government of Manuel Zelaya, currently advising the presidency, Dessiré occupies today the Undersecretariat of the Presidency and is a substitute member of the National Investment Council (CNI). His name sounds to replace Lesly Cerna in the Secretariat of the Presidency, in case the latter is transferred to Defense. His rise is more explained by family ties than by an independent career in the political or technical. On May 15, 2024, he was elected president of the Court of Honor of the Bar Association of Honduras (CAH), in a controversial session backed by the claiming, union and homeland and justice fronts. However, his appointment was challenged by Ana Cardona Herrera, who claimed to have been previously elected in March by majority of the members. This episode presented tensions within the guild and questions about transparency in the conformation of leadership. Flores Dubón represents a continuity of the political project of free in different state instances. His eventual arrival in the Secretariat of the Presidency would imply assuming the coordination of the cabinet, the link with the Congress and a central role in the definition of the Executive Agenda. data.title: Xiomara Castro pide el voto para Rixi durante asamblea de la Amhon en Roatán
data.description: La paradisiaca isla de Roatán , en el departamento de Islas de la Bahía, acogió la 34 asamblea de la Asociación de Municipios de Honduras (Amhon), con la participación de los 298 alcaldes y alcaldesas del país. La reunión anual de los ediles comenzó el lunes 26 con la inscripción de los participantes. La presidenta Xiomara Castro fue invitada de honor y llegó este martes al magno evento que se desarrolla en las instalaciones del Ministerio Apostólico Visión del Reino. Asimismo, asistieron Luis Redondo, presidente del Congreso Nacional, y Rebeca Ráquel Obando, presidenta de la Corte Suprema de Justicia. El objetivo de la asamblea de la Amhon es poder desarrollar una plataforma de diálogo y acción conjunta entre los alcaldes y alcaldesas, con el Gobierno Central y la Cooperación Internacional. Uno de los momentos que más llamó la atención de los presentes fue cuando la presidenta Xiomara Castro ofreció en su discurso pidió el voto para Rixi Moncada , candidata del Partido Libertad y Refundación (Libre) en el poder. “Para que todo esto continúe los invito a que apoyemos a la mujer que le dará continuidad a los proyectos de refundación , a la abogada Rixi Moncada Godoy”, expresó la mandataria de los hondureños en Roatán. La invitación a votar por Rixi Moncada, quien este martes presentó su renuncia como ministra de Defensa de cara a las elecciones generales, no fue del agrado para la oposición, ya que aseguraron que no se puede politizar la asamblea de alcaldes. Xiomara Castro mencionó además otros temas de país, impulsando su proyecto de refundación de la patria , el cual debe ser convertido en una práctica cotidiana. Destacó que más de 24 mil millones de lempiras se han transferido puntualmente a las municipalidades en los últimos tres años y cuatro meses de su gestión gubernamental. “Estas transferencias a las municipalidades son una expresión de la voluntad de mi gobierno, desde el socialismo democrático, para descentralizar los recursos del Estado”, apuntó Xiomara Castro. Hizo énfasis en los logros de su gobierno como la reparación de escuelas, construcción de caminos productivos, cajas rurales, pavimentación de carretera s, entre otros proyectos que se realizan con las municipalidades. Castro destacó además la contratación de cinco mil maestros, programa de la merienda escolar y la matrícula gratis que ha restituido el derecho de una educación pública , gratuita, bilingüe y morazanista. Igualmente, reiteró la construcción de ocho hospitales a nivel nacional, un materno infantil, cuatro centros neonatales y dos nosocomios de trauma en San Pedro Sula y Tegucigalpa Rom MacNab, alcalde de Roatán en su condición de anfitrión, dio la bienvenida a los alcaldes del país. "Gracias por estar aquí. Gracias por lo que hacen cada día desde sus alcaldías. Y gracias por creer, como yo, que desde lo local se puede transformar a Honduras", acotó. La 34 asamblea de la Amhon finaliza este miércoles con las conclusiones y los acuerdos con el gobierno central y los organismos internacionales.
data.translatedTitle: Xiomara Castro asks for the vote for Rixi during the Ashon Assembly in Roatán
data.translatedDescription: The paradisiaca Island of Roatán, in the department of islands of the Bay, hosted the 34 Assembly of the Association of Municipalities of Honduras (AMHON), with the participation of the 298 mayors and mayors of the country. The annual meeting of the mayor began on Monday 26 with the registration of the participants. President Xiomara Castro was invited to honor and arrived on Tuesday to the great event that takes place at the facilities of the Apostolic Ministry Vision of the Kingdom. Likewise, Luis Redondo, president of the National Congress, and Rebeca Ráquel Obando, president of the Supreme Court of Justice attended. The objective of the AMHON Assembly is to be able to develop a platform for dialogue and joint action between mayors and mayors, with the central government and international cooperation. One of the moments that most caught the attention of those present was when President Xiomara Castro offered in her speech requested the vote for Rixi Moncada, candidate of the Freedom and Refoundation Party (free) in power. "For all this to continue I invite you to support the woman who will give continuity to the re -foundation projects, the lawyer Rixi Moncada Godoy," said the president of the Hondurans in Roatán. The invitation to vote for Rixi Moncada, who on Tuesday presented his resignation as Minister of Defense for the general elections, was not to the opposition, since they assured that the mayors assembly cannot be politicized. Xiomara Castro also mentioned other country issues, promoting its project for the refounding of the homeland, which must be converted into a daily practice. He stressed that more than 24 billion lempiras have been transferred promptly to municipalities in the last three years and four months of their government management. "These transfers to municipalities are an expression of the will of my government, from democratic socialism, to decentralize state resources," said Xiomara Castro. He emphasized his government's achievements such as school repair, construction of productive roads, rural boxes, road paving, among other projects that are carried out with the municipalities. Castro also highlighted the hiring of five thousand teachers, a free school snack program and the free registration that has restored the right of a free, bilingual and morazanist public education. He also reiterated the construction of eight hospitals nationwide, a child maternal, four neonatal centers and two trauma hospitals in San Pedro Sula and Tegucigalpa Rom Macnab, mayor of Roatán in his status as host, welcomed the mayors of the country. "Thank you for being here. Thank you for what they do every day from its mayorships. And thanks for believing, like me, that from the local you can transform to Honduras," he said. The 34 Assembly of the AMHON ends this Wednesday with the conclusions and agreements with the central government and international organizations.

data.title: ¿Purga interna en la banda "Los Galeano"? Cuatro asesinatos sacuden Jutiapa
data.description: Docentes y padres de familia de la escuela Christian Academy, en el municipio de Jutiapa, Atlántida, no dan crédito a la repentina muerte de la niña Bianca Galeas (de 7 años) y su padre Jorge Antonio Galeano Osorio (de 55). El doble homicidio ocurrió la tarde del lunes entre las aldeas Cacao y Agua Caliente, frente a la carretera CA-13. De acuerdo con testigos, Jorge Galeano se encontraba dentro de su vehículo tipo pick-up y se disponía a bajarse en una llantera cuando sicarios, a bordo de una motocicleta, se le acercaron y abrieron fuego. Galeano murió en el lugar, mientras que su hija resultó herida por los disparos. Fue trasladada a un centro asistencial, donde se reportó su fallecimiento. En el ataque también resultó herido el dueño de la llantera, quien se encuentra fuera de peligro. Familiares de Jorge Galeano recogieron su cuerpo y lo trasladaron a su vivienda. El cadáver no fue llevado a la morgue de La Ceiba. Según se conoció, Galeano era un conocido ganadero de la zona.​​​​​​ La escuela Christian Academy emitió un acuerdo de duelo lamentando lo sucedido. “Con profundo dolor, la comunidad educativa lamenta el sensible fallecimiento de nuestra amada estudiante de kínder”, expresa el comunicado. La Policía Nacional ha manejado el caso con hermetismo y solo ha brindado información escueta sobre los hechos violentos. “No se hizo levantamiento, ya que cuando la policía llegó ya se habían llevado el cuerpo”, dijo Angelina Galeas, portavoz policial. La tarde del martes, se reportaron otras dos muertes en el municipio de Jutiapa, específicamente en el desvío a La Danta, en la comunidad de Corralitos. Una de las víctimas fue identificada como Wilmer Dubón, mientras que la otra persona no fue reconocida. Las autoridades no confirmaron si este doble crimen está relacionado con el asesinato de Jorge Galeano y su hija. Tampoco se han revelado los móviles de ninguno de los hechos. Durante la Operación Candado, realizada en 2016 en Jutiapa, la Policía capturó a siete personas vinculadas a la banda “Los Galeano”. En esa ocasión, se les decomisó un arsenal de armas de grueso calibre. Entre los detenidos figuraban Jorge Antonio Galeano Osorio y su hermano Andrés de Jesús Galeano. Residentes del sector indicaron que las recientes muertes podrían estar vinculadas a una “limpieza” dentro de la banda, dedicada al asalto a mano armada, robo a repartidores y sicariato. “En otras ocasiones ya se han reportado muertes relacionadas a ellos, así como capturas”, comentaron. Ayer por la tarde también se reportó la incautación de armas de fuego dentro de un vehículo Ford color negro, hecho que podría estar relacionado con los asesinatos en Jutiapa. Sin embargo, la Policía no ha emitido un informe oficial al respecto. En la colonia El Pedregal, de la aldea Sambo Creek, en La Ceiba, sujetos armados ingresaron a la vivienda de José Alfredo Navarro, de 46 años, y le dispararon hasta quitarle la vida. El hecho ocurrió alrededor de las 9:00 pm del lunes. Navarro era originario de Jutiapa. En la escena del crimen se decomisaron dos teléfonos celulares, los cuales serán analizados para determinar si el asesinato guarda relación con los hechos violentos ocurridos en Jutiapa. “Los dos teléfonos que se levantaron van a estar siendo vaciados para determinar si están ligados a otras muertes. Por ahora se maneja enemistades personales”, informó Angelina Galeas, portavoz policial. ETIQUETA DE TRANSPARENCIA: Este artículo fue revisado y aprobado por un editor con ayuda de una herramienta de inteligencia artificial.
data.translatedTitle: Internal purge in the band "Los Galeano"? Four murders shake Jutiapa
data.translatedDescription: Teachers and parents of the Christian Academy School, in the municipality of Jutiapa, Atlántida, do not give credit to the sudden death of the girl Bianca Galeas (7 years) and her father Jorge Antonio Galeano Osorio (55). The double homicide occurred on Monday afternoon between the cocoa and hot water villages, in front of the CA-13 road. According to witnesses, Jorge Galeano was inside his pick-up type vehicle and was about to get off in a wounder when hitmen, aboard a motorcycle, they approached and opened fire. Galeano died in the place, while his daughter was injured by the shots. She was transferred to a health center, where her death was reported. In the attack, the owner of the Llantera was also injured, who is out of danger. Relatives of Jorge Galeano picked up his body and transferred him to his home. The body was not taken to the morgue of the CEIBA. As it was known, Galeano was a well -known livestock in the area. The Christian Academy school issued a grieving agreement regretting what happened. "With deep pain, the educational community regrets the sensitive death of our beloved Kindergarten," says the statement. The National Police has handled the case with secrecy and has only provided for sure information about violent facts. "No lifting was made, since when the police arrived they had already taken their body," said Angelina Galeas, a police spokesman. On Tuesday afternoon, two other deaths were reported in the municipality of Jutiapa, specifically in the detour to Danta, in the community of Corralitos. One of the victims was identified as Wilmer Dubón, while the other person was not recognized. The authorities did not confirm whether this double crime is related to the murder of Jorge Galeano and his daughter. Nor have the mobiles of any of the facts been revealed. During operation padlock, held in 2016 in Jutiapa, the Police captured seven people linked to the band “Los Galeano”. On that occasion, they were seized an arsenal of thick caliber weapons. Among the detainees were Jorge Antonio Galeano Osorio and his brother Andrés de Jesús Galeano. Residents of the sector indicated that recent deaths could be linked to a "cleaning" inside the band, dedicated to armed hand assault, robbery of distributors and sicariate. "On other occasions, deaths related to them have already been reported, as well as captures," they said. Yesterday afternoon, the seizure of firearms inside a black Ford vehicle was also reported, a fact that could be related to the murders in Jutiapa. However, the police have not issued an official report in this regard. In the El Pedregal neighborhood, from the Sambo Creek village, in La Ceiba, armed subjects entered the house of José Alfredo Navarro, 46, and shot him until he took his life. The incident occurred around 9:00 pm on Monday. Navarro was originally from Jutiapa. In the crime scene two cell phones were confiscated, which will be analyzed to determine if the murder is related to the violent events that occurred in Jutiapa. "The two phones that were built will be emptied to determine if they are linked to other deaths. For now personal enmity is handled," said Angelina Galeas, police spokesman. data.title: Abierta investigación contra  empleados del BCH y dos fiscales por robo de L88 millones
data.description: La audiencia para presentar pruebas contra Francia Sofía Medina, fiscal acusada de sustraer 88 millones de lempiras del Banco Central de Honduras (BCH), sigue pendiente, ya que el tribunal aún no ha fijado una fecha. Las autoridades del Ministerio Público (MP) informaron que la investigación sigue abierta contra empleados del BCH que entregaron el dinero a Medina sin cumplir con los requisitos legales. También se investiga a dos de los cinco fiscales inicialmente señalados por su supuesta participación en la desaparición del dinero, el cual estaba bajo resguardo como evidencia en casos en curso del Ministerio Público. Medina fue capturada el 30 de noviembre de 2023 en su residencia en San Pedro Sula, luego de que el MP identificara supuestas irregularidades cometidas por la acusadora pública. Según el MP, los 42 delitos que se le imputan ya cuentan con pruebas documentales. De ser hallada culpable en juicio oral y público, enfrentaría una condena mínima de 40 años de prisión. Entre los delitos señalados figuran: lavado de activos, enriquecimiento ilícito, uso de información privilegiada, ocultación y destrucción de evidencias, así como 38 cargos por falsificación de documentos públicos. Las investigaciones indican que la fiscal realizó 38 retiros del BCH, sumando 88 millones de lempiras, sin seguir los procedimientos establecidos por el MP. Desde 2021, Medina habría empezado a retirar fondos sin cumplir con los protocolos que exigen una autorización secuencial del fiscal del caso, del coordinador, y del subdirector, previo a la entrega en el banco. El caso salió a la luz luego de que los apoderados legales de una paleontóloga, a quien le habían decomisado 63,000 dólares, reclamaran la devolución del dinero. El BCH respondió que ya había sido entregado, lo que motivó al MP a solicitar un informe. La institución financiera informó entonces que se habían retirado 88 millones de lempiras que figuraban como evidencia. El MP sostiene que el BCH tenía responsabilidad jurídica sobre esos fondos y actuaba como garante. El 4 de diciembre de 2023, un juez emitió orden de captura contra Germán René Silva, pareja de la fiscal Medina y también fiscal, quien se encuentra prófugo. Según la Agencia Técnica de Investigación Criminal (ATIC), hay indicios de su participación en el delito. Ese mismo día, el MP aseguró 36 bienes propiedad de Francia Medina en los departamentos de Comayagua y Cortés, incluyendo siete inmuebles, 20 vehículos y nueve cuentas bancarias.
data.translatedTitle: Open investigation against BCH employees and two prosecutors for theft of L88 million
data.translatedDescription: The hearing to present evidence against France Sofía Medina, prosecutor accused of subtracting 88 million lempiras from the Central Bank of Honduras (BCH), is still pending, since the court has not yet set a date. The authorities of the Public Ministry (MP) reported that the investigation is still open against BCH employees who delivered the money to Medina without complying with the legal requirements. Two of the five prosecutors are also investigated initially indicated for their alleged participation in the disappearance of money, which was under shelter as evidence in cases of the Public Ministry. Medina was captured on November 30, 2023 at its residence in San Pedro Sula, after the MP identified alleged irregularities committed by the public prosecutor. According to the MP, the 42 crimes that are already charged with documentary evidence. If they were found guilty in oral and public trial, it would face a minimum sentence of 40 years in prison. Among the crimes indicated are: money laundering, illicit enrichment, use of privileged information, concealment and destruction of evidence, as well as 38 positions for falsification of public documents. The investigations indicate that the prosecutor made 38 withdrawals from the BCH, adding 88 million lempiras, without following the procedures established by the MP. Since 2021, Medina would have begun to withdraw funds without complying with the protocols that require a sequential authorization of the case prosecutor, the coordinator, and the deputy director, prior to the delivery in the bank. The case came to light after the legal proxies of a paleontologist, who had seized $ 63,000, claimed the return of money. The BCH replied that it had already been delivered, which motivated the MP to request a report. The financial institution then reported that 88 million lempiras had been withdrawn that were evidence. The MP argues that the BCH had legal responsibility on those funds and acted as guarantor. On December 4, 2023, a judge issued a arrest warrant against Germán René Silva, a couple of prosecutor Medina and also a fiscal, who is a fugitive. According to the Technical Agency for Criminal Investigation (ATIC), there are indications of their participation in the crime. That same day, the MP assured 36 goods owned by France Medina in the departments of Comayagua and Cortés, including seven properties, 20 vehicles and nine bank accounts.

data.title: Presidenta asume Defensa y oficializa a Javier Bu como nuevo canciller
data.description: Tegucigalpa, Honduras.- La presidenta de la República, Xiomara Castro , oficializó este miércoles el nombramiento de dos nuevos funcionarios en su gabinete, tras la salida de tres altos cargos que competirán como parte de la fórmula presidencial del partido Libertad y Refundación (Libre) en las elecciones generales del próximo 30 de noviembre. Así lo dio a conocer a través de su cuenta oficial de "X", donde a su vez anunció que ella misma tomará el mando de la Secretaría de Defensa. "Las funciones de la Secretaría de Defensa Nacional serán asumidas por mi persona, en mi condición de comandanta general de las Fuerzas Armadas", escribió Castro. El abogado Javier Efraín Bú Soto , actual embajador de Honduras en Estados Unidos, fue designado como nuevo secretario de Relaciones Exteriores y Cooperación Internacional, en sustitución de Eduardo Enrique Reina, quien dejó el cargo para integrarse como designado presidencial. También fue nombrado Longino Becerra como nuevo titular de la Secretaría de Derechos Humanos, tras la salida de Angélica Álvarez, quien también se une a la campaña política en calidad de designada presidencial. "Agradezco profundamente a quienes han ejercido con responsabilidad y eficiencia estos altos cargos, brindando un valioso servicio a la patria", declaró Castro. Las renuncias se producen a pocos días de cumplirse el plazo legal para que los funcionarios públicos que aspiran a cargos de elección popular abandonen sus puestos, tal como exige el artículo 240 de la Ley Electoral. La fecha límite es el 30 de mayo, exactamente seis meses antes de los comicios generales programados para el 30 de noviembre.
data.translatedTitle: President assumes defense and formalizes Javier BU as a new chancellor
data.translatedDescription: Tegucigalpa, Honduras.- The President of the Republic, Xiomara Castro, formalized on Wednesday the appointment of two new officials in their cabinet, after the departure of three senior positions that will compete as part of the presidential formula of the Freedom and Refoundation Party (free) in the general elections of November 30. This was announced through her official "X" account, where she announced that she will take command of the Secretariat of Defense. "The functions of the Ministry of National Defense will be assumed by me, in my status as a general command of the Armed Forces," Castro wrote. The lawyer Javier Efraín Bú Soto, current Ambassador of Honduras in the United States, was appointed as the new Secretary of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation, replacing Eduardo Enrique Reina, who left office to integrate as an presidential designated. Longino Becerra was also appointed as the new head of the Secretariat of Human Rights, after the departure of Angélica Álvarez, who also joins the political campaign as a presidential designated. "I deeply thank those who have exercised with responsibility and efficiency these high positions, providing valuable service to the homeland," Castro said. The resignations occur a few days after the legal deadline for public officials who aspire to positions of popular election abandon their positions, as required by article 240 of the Electoral Law. The deadline is May 30, exactly six months before the general elections scheduled for November 30.

data.title: Suspenden sesión en el Congreso Nacional en medio de hermetismo y tensión
data.description: Tegucigalpa, Honduras.- Después de tres horas de espera, la sesión del Congreso Nacional no duró ni cinco minutos en un ambiente de tensión, hermetismo, misterio. El Hemiciclo mantuvo las puertas vedadas a los medios, pero los informes mostraban fuerte presencia de seguridad privada, lo que fue denunciada por los diputados de oposición. La oposición tenía lista una moción con alrededor de 74 diputados para aprobar el acta de la moción anterior, en virtud de que tenían informes que la Junta Directiva, quería aprobar convenios y préstamos internacionales metiendo en el fondo el presupuesto de las elecciones de noviembre del Consejo Nacional Electoral. La oposición exigía aprobar el acta y en una nueva sesión conocer y aprobar el presupuesto de 1,737 millones de lempiras que el CNE ha pedido para las elecciones de este año, según lo dio a conocer la consejera presidenta del Consejo Nacional Electoral (CNE), Cossette López. Diputados de la oposición están a la expectativa de ser convocados nuevamente, por lo que no quieren abandonar el Hemiciclo Legislativo, arguyendo que podría haber un "madrugón". "Ahí están todos los de la bancada de Libre sentados, yo supongo que lo que quieren es que nos vayamos, convocar y aprobar esto sin el cuórum debido, otro madrugón", manifestó Jorge Cálix, instando a presupuesto de elecciones.
data.translatedTitle: Session suspend in the National Congress in the midst of secrecy and tension
data.translatedDescription: Tegucigalpa, Honduras.- After three hours of waiting, the National Congress session did not last even five minutes in an environment of tension, secrecy, mystery. The hemicycle kept the doors closed to the media, but the reports showed a strong presence of private security, which was denounced by opposition deputies. The opposition had a motion with around 74 deputies to approve the act of the previous motion, because they had reports that the Board of Directors wanted to approve international agreements and loans by putting in the background the budget of the November elections of the National Electoral Council. The opposition demanded to approve the minutes and in a new session know and approve the budget of 1,737 million lempiras that the CNE has asked for this year's elections, as announced by the president of the National Electoral Council (CNE), Cossette López. Opposition deputies are in expectation of being summoned again, so they do not want to abandon the legislative hemicycle, arguing that there could be a "early riser." "There are all those on the free bank sitting, I suppose that what they want is to go, convene and pass this without the quorum due, another early morning," said Jorge Calix, urging election budget.

data.title: Oposición busca cerrar sesión y votar acta pendiente en Congreso Nacional
data.description: Tegucigalpa, Honduras.- Diputados de la oposición tienen lista una moción de orden para que el Congreso Nacional cierre la sesión programada para este martes 27 de mayo y le dé espacio exclusivo para votar por un acta pendiente desde hace tres semanas. La moción respaldada por alrededor de 74 diputados, señala que la Ley del Poder Legislativo, en su artículo 67, permite presentar mociones de orden previas a cualquier asunto en discusión. El documento, que incluye las firmas de los legisladores que apoyan la moción, denuncia que el oficialismo ha estado usando las sesiones para "dar largas" y confundir a la opinión pública, con el fin de ganar tiempo y proteger intereses políticos. La oposición refiere que la transparencia y la celeridad en la discusión del acta son esenciales para fortalecer la democracia en el país. A su vez, argumentan que la moción en mención cumple con todos los requisitos para ser considerada como prioritaria.
data.translatedTitle: Opposition seeks to close and vote pending act in the National Congress
data.translatedDescription: Tegucigalpa, Honduras.- Opposition deputies have a motion of order for the National Congress to close the session scheduled for this Tuesday, May 27 and give it exclusive space to vote for a pending act for three weeks. The motion backed by around 74 deputies, indicates that the Law of Legislative Power, in its article 67, allows to present motions prior to any matter under discussion. The document, which includes the signatures of the legislators who support the motion, denounces that the ruling has been using the sessions to "give long" and confuse public opinion, in order to gain time and protect political interests. The opposition says that transparency and speed in the discussion of the act are essential to strengthen democracy in the country. In turn, they argue that the mention motion meets all the requirements to be considered as a priority.

data.title: Haïti : Démocratie entravée, Constitution en débat (1987–2025)
data.description: Analyse approfondie de l'évolution du processus constitutionnel haïtien de 1987 à 2025, entre aspirations démocratiques, blocages politiques, amendements controversés et tentatives de refonte, dans un contexte de crise institutionnelle persistante. - Perspectives
data.translatedTitle: Haiti: hampered democracy, constitution in debate (1987–2025)
data.translatedDescription: In -depth analysis of the evolution of the Haitian constitutional process from 1987 to 2025, between democratic aspirations, political blockages, controversial amendments and attempted redesign, in a context of persistent institutional crisis. - Perspectives

data.title: Haïti – Justice : L'avant-projet de Constitution mettrait en péril l'indépendance judiciaire, alerte l'Apm
data.description: L'Association professionnelle des magistrats (Apm) critique l'avant-projet de Constitution, publié le 21 mai 2025, dénonçant l'insuffisance de garanties pour l'indépendance du pouvoir judiciaire et l'absence de consultation du secteur. - Perspectives
data.translatedTitle: Haiti-Justice: the preliminary draft constitution would jeopardize judicial independence, alerts the APM
data.translatedDescription: The Professional Association of Magistrates (APM) criticizes the preliminary draft constitution, published on May 21, 2025, denouncing the insufficiency of guarantees for the independence of the judiciary and the absence of consultation of the sector. - Perspectives

data.title: Crise : 60 organisations tirent la sonnette d'alarme sur la situation sécuritaire et humanitaire en Haïti
data.description: Le Clio, regroupement d'une soixantaine d'Ongs, alerte sur la crise humanitaire en Haïti et appelle à une réponse urgente et respectueuse des droits. - Dépêches
data.translatedTitle: Crisis: 60 organizations sound the alarm on the security and humanitarian situation in Haiti
data.translatedDescription: The Clio, grouping of around sixty NGOs, alert to the humanitarian crisis in Haiti and calls for an urgent and respectful response. - dispatches

data.title: Haïti-Société : Entre désastre humanitaire et crise socioéconomique au Plateau central
data.description: Situation lamentable au haut Plateau central, qui croule sous des tonnes de déchets, dans un contexte de fuite de milliers de personnes déplacées, chassées par la terreur des gangs terroristes armés. - A travers Haiti
data.translatedTitle: Haiti-Société: between humanitarian disaster and socioeconomic crisis on the central plateau
data.translatedDescription: Lovable situation on the high central plateau, which is crumbling under tons of waste, in a context of leakage of thousands of displaced people, hunted by the terror of armed terrorist gangs. - Through Haiti

data.title: Haïti : In memoriam Didier Dominique, Éclaireur des horizons nouveaux
data.description: Hommage à Didier Dominique, intellectuel engagé, syndicaliste infatigable, penseur de la ville et de la culture haïtienne, figure majeure des luttes sociales, décédé le 18 mai 2025. - Documents
data.translatedTitle: Haiti: in Memoriam Didier Dominique, scout new horizons
data.translatedDescription: Tribute to Didier Dominique, committed intellectual, tireless trade unionist, thinker of the city and Haitian culture, a major figure in social struggles, died May 18, 2025. - Documents

data.title: Haïti : Infirmières et infirmiers en première ligne, mais toujours en marge
data.description: En Haïti, les infirmières et infirmiers jouent un rôle vital dans le système de santé, mais restent sous-payé·e·s, marginalisé·e·s et exposé·e·s à de multiples risques. Un cri d'alarme pour une profession essentielle, mais oubliée. - Perspectives
data.translatedTitle: Haiti: first line nurses, but still on the sidelines
data.translatedDescription: In Haiti, nurses play a vital role in the health system, but remain underpaid, marginalized and exposed to multiple risks. A cry of alarm for an essential, but forgotten profession. - Perspectives

data.title: Amériques (Haïti) : Albert Ramdin entame officiellement son mandat en tant que nouveau secrétaire général de l'Oea

data.translatedDescription: The first commitments of Surinameds Albert Ramchand Ramdin, after his taking office, this Monday, May 26, 2025, as a new secretary general of the Organization of American States (OEA). - Perspectives

data.title: Haïti : Torcel et Pernier, au cœur d'un vaste réseau criminel
data.description: La Pnh frappe le gang Kraze Baryè à Torcel et Pernier : plusieurs morts, des armes saisies, mais Vitelhomme Innocent échappe encore à la capture. Comment le chef de gang parvient-il à fuir, malgré sa traque nationale et internationale ? - Perspectives
data.translatedTitle: Haiti: Torcel and Pernier, at the heart of a vast criminal network
data.translatedDescription: The PNH strikes the gang Kraze Baryè in Torcel and Pernier: several dead, weapons seized, but Vitelhomme Innocent still escapes the capture. How does the gang leader manage to flee, despite his national and international hunt? - Perspectives

data.title: Haïti / Crise énergétique : Entre revendications locales, sécurité nationale et désastre agricole dans l'Artibonite
data.description: Crise énergétique en Haïti : Tandis que Port-au-Prince retrouve partiellement l'électricité, la vallée de l'Artibonite subit des inondations catastrophiques dues à l'arrêt de la centrale de Péligre. Entre insécurité, tensions sociales et désastre agricole, la situation devient critique. - Perspectives
data.translatedTitle: Haiti / Energy crisis: between local demands, national security and agricultural disaster in Artibonite
data.translatedDescription: Energy crisis in Haiti: while Port-au-Prince partially finds electricity, the Artibonite valley undergoes catastrophic floods due to the stop of the Peligre power station. Between insecurity, social tensions and agricultural disaster, the situation becomes critical. - Perspectives

data.title: Lessons from the property tax
data.description: DR JAMELIA HARRIS OFTENTIMES those who critique the current state of development in TT look to the North or Far East with aspirational eyes. Why can't we be like Canada? Like Germany? Like Singapore? If we assess the debates around the property tax and the impending repeal of the Property Tax Act, we will find some answers. The first, and most obvious, is that most developed countries have a property tax. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development notes that across all of Europe only two countries do not levy property tax: Liechtenstein and Malta. There are over 40 countries in Europe. The reason for property taxes being so commonplace is simple: they offer a reliable and stable source of government revenue. The fiscal arguments are clear. The economic arguments are also clear. From an economic perspective, of all possible taxes, a property tax is least distortionary as it has the least impact on behaviour – a higher property tax is unlikely to cause someone to sell their home. The main challenge of the property tax is that it requires political will and public buy-in – as we have clearly seen here in TT. The second lesson is that we have a very low appetite for paying taxes – lower than in most developed countries. In all developed countries the social contract is such that citizens pay taxes; sometimes up to 12 per cent in property tax and 40 per cent in income tax if we use the UK as an example. That said, the UK does not have the highest tax rates in Europe or globally. The residential rate of the property tax in TT is two per cent, reduced from three per cent. The understanding in most developed countries is that to fund public goods and services taxes must be paid. This social contract is not very strong in TT. There are multiple reasons for the breakdown of this social contract – top of the list are corruption and mismanagement. Also on this list is the belief by some citizens of their right to public goods and services, but not their responsibility for paying into the collective pot. The third is that we are not serious about diversifying our tax base. We have been having the diversification conservation for most of our existence as an independent country. One of the benefits of a diversified economy is a diversified tax base so that the government is not overly dependent on any one tax source. Beyond diversifying the economy, the government can directly diversify the tax base to ensure multiple tax sources can be tapped into. This is what developed countries do. This is what the property tax was intended to do. The fourth is that we are a society with poor enforcement of laws. We see this daily. With the property tax, a large share of residents did not pay the tax. The consequences: nothing. In most developed countries, non-payment of tax is met with a warning, a fine, and, at worse, prison time. And fifth, and possibly most concerning, we do not reward playing by the rules. In contrast to the group that did not pay, the other share of the population duly complied with the law and paid their taxes. Finance Minister Davendranath Tancoo promised a refund; which the Prime Minister swiftly refuted. Kamla Persad-Bissessar's response: we told them not to pay, reflecting on her position as then-opposition leader. In other words, you should have refused to comply with the law. Such advice would rarely come from one of the highest offices in the average developed country, far less from a seasoned lawyer. We really need to look in the mirror in TT. We want to be more developed. We want progress. But progress requires change. Let's change our tax base and introduce the property tax. No thank you. Let's change our revenue collection system and collect revenues more efficiently with the TT Revenue Authority. No thank you. Let's change our driving behaviour with the demerit points system. No thank you. If the only thing we are willing to change is our government, and not the underlying structures of our economy, fiscal system and society, then we will change little and our quest for continued development will be elusive. Dr Jamelia Harris is an economist The post Lessons from the property tax appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .

Finance Minister Davendranath Tancoo promised a refund; which the Prime Minister swiftly refuted. Kamla Persad-Bissessar's response: we told them not to pay, reflecting on her position as then-opposition leader. In other words, you should have refused to comply with the law. Such advice would rarely come from one of the highest offices in the average developed country, far less from a seasoned lawyer. We really need to look in the mirror in TT. We want to be more developed. We want progress. But progress requires change. Let's change our tax base and introduce the property tax. No thank you. Let's change our revenue collection system and collect revenues more efficiently with the TT Revenue Authority. No thank you. Let's change our driving behaviour with the demerit points system. No thank you. If the only thing we are willing to change is our government, and not the underlying structures of our economy, fiscal system and society, then we will change little and our quest for continued development will be elusive. Dr Jamelia Harris is an economist The post Lessons from the property tax appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .

data.title: Migrant crisis deepens
data.description: FROM ALL sides, pressure is mounting on Venezuelan migrants. In the US, the Supreme Court on May 19 allowed the Trump administration to strip at least 340,000 of temporary protected status, reportedly the largest such dismantling of amnesty in modern American history. The humanitarian crisis these people have fled – characterised by widespread hunger and malnutrition, the rise of armed gangs, crumbling infrastructure and deep political repression – has only worsened. On May 25, the Nicolas Maduro regime claimed victory in regional and legislative elections, compounding the fraudulence of last year’s widely discredited presidential poll. In TT, thousands of Venezuelans today face deep uncertainty. The April 28 general election result has done little to clarify their fate. The PNM government, which had at one stage allowed at least 35,300 to live and work here under a renewable permit scheme, under Stuart Young agreed to co-operate with Trump administration officials’ efforts to tackle the so-called threat of the Tren de Aragua gang, an invasive threat used to justify the invocation of the Alien Enemies Act. But the US intelligence community, in a declassified memo published in the American press on May 5, assessed the gang to have no ties with the Maduro regime. The newly elected UNC administration, meanwhile, is yet to address robustly the future of the Venezuelan migrant scheme amid a rising tide of rhetoric against migrants. Yet, deafening silence will soon become unsustainable given the prospect of a full-blown conflagration. In an interview with this newspaper on May 20, Dr Anthony Gonzales, the former head of the Institute for International Relations at UWI, St Augustine, noted the Supreme Court ruling alone will pile more pressure on TT. “It is a cause for concern,” he said. “Venezuela is not in a good position to receive these deportees.” This country’s treatment of migrants is not just an economic issue. Nor is it just a political one. It is an ethical issue that demands a strong moral compass. Unfortunately, that clarity has been lacking in the years since 2015, even as the total number of people fleeing our closest neighbour has risen to at least 7.9 million in one of the largest humanitarian displacements the world has ever seen. The state dragged its feet with the admission of thousands of children into schools; some were killed during reckless refoulement activities in open seas. The economic advantages generated by a supplemented workforce have been conveniently ignored. Venezuelan migrants have been broadly brushed as criminals, even as some continue to succumb to local crime. But soon, with this crisis deepening, officials might have little choice but to come face to face with the moral implications of their own policymaking, or lack thereof. The post Migrant crisis deepens appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .

data.title: Decentralising long overdue
data.description: THE EDITOR: For decades, the decentralisation of government offices has been widely discussed, but meaningful progress has yet to be made. It is time to move beyond talk and take decisive action to make this long-overdue transition a reality. Relocating government offices out of Port of Spain offers clear advantages for the nation. Rental costs in outlying areas are significantly lower, which will mean substantial savings for the state. It would also help ease the severe traffic congestion faced by thousands of commuters daily, reducing stress and improving the overall quality of life. A less congested Port of Spain would result in better air quality, improved mobility, and a more inviting environment for tourism and leisure activities. Overall, these changes would enhance the city’s appeal and benefit public health. Decentralisation also provides an important opportunity to stimulate economic growth in less developed areas. Encouraging investment, creating jobs, and improving infrastructure outside the capital city would promote balanced regional development. At the May 22 post-Cabinet media briefing, the Prime Minister highlighted the high cost of government rentals, many of which operate under expired leases and lack proper fire, health, and safety certifications. This situation underscores the urgent need for stronger oversight and a thorough review of rental agreements. Moreover, discussions about rent control should not be confined solely to government leases. The discussions must also extend to the private rental market to protect vulnerable citizens from exploitative and unsafe living or working conditions. Additionally, the expansion of remote work and the acceleration of public service digitisation offer practical, forward-looking solutions to reduce the government’s reliance on physical office space. These strategies can significantly lower operational costs while enhancing efficiency, flexibility, and convenience for both public servants and the citizens they serve. The rationale for decentralisation is both clear and compelling. What is required now is the political will and steadfast commitment to implementation – qualities I am confident this new administration will demonstrate in due course. LEISHA S DHORAY via e-mail The post Decentralising long overdue appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .

data.title: Good moveby Ministerof Transport
data.description: THE EDITOR: I like what Transport and Civil Aviation Minister Eli Zakour is selling. This rubber hits the road, feet on the ground, walking the factory managerial and leadership style should not only be encouraged, but also implemented by all his ministerial peers. Zakour has taken an unprecedented stance by refusing to use his entitled Priority Bus Route (PBR) pass. He argues that by experiencing the roadways and traffic as an ordinary citizen he can better understand, address and correctly steward his role. Unfortunately, the mandate to serve us, the people, is lost on many of our elected and appointed leaders today. Many live lives very distinct from those whom their decisions directly impact. They are shielded and isolated from the consequences (and sometimes nuisances) that their policies, actions or inactions create. No reasonable person believed the former prime minister tightened his belt in the same way he expected us to, nor did anyone believe for a second that Colm Imbert was “vex with himself” regarding the increasing fuel costs. But Zakour says that his tenure of service will be different. That he will acquaint himself with the same experience on the roadways as the average driver. And simply put, I'm all for it. Now we’ll have someone in a position to enact change experiencing the rote morning creep towards the capital. This may lead them to support work-from-home legislation. Now they, too, can feel the danger of the westbound rightmost lane being abruptly halved at every stop; from Tacarigua to St Augustine. Leading them to enquire why the turning-lane traffic signal isn't lengthened at pick-up and drop-off times. Now they can join us in the defensive driving required to avoid the many potholes that riddle our nation's roads. Urging them to offer aid or help streamline the repair work that the boroughs and counties do. Maybe, just maybe, when those in positions to enact change experience the same delays, inconveniences and lacklustre customer service, then we can see real positive and lasting change taking place. So go ahead, minister, because it sounds good to me. Keep left, except when overtaking, tune in to your favourite talk show, lean back and get comfortable, because it's gonna be a long ride. JON HUBERT BRISTOL Arima The post Good moveby Ministerof Transport appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .

data.title: Spoilers look strong as Brothers T20 League reaches quarterfinal stage
data.description: Debe Spoilers may be the team to beat in the playoffs of the Brothers Premier League T20 tournament after ending the group phase with a perfect five wins. Spoilers topped Group C with 15 points and are the top-ranked team heading into the quarterfinals. The Debe outfit will face the eight-seeded HYO in quarterfinal one at the Brothers Recreation Ground in Williamsville, on May 28, at 7 pm. In one of their most recent group matches, Spoilers defeated Trixstaz by seven wickets in a high-scoring encounter. Batting first, Trixstaz posted a massive 203/3 in 20 overs with Amit Bedassie cracking 101 not out. Avalon Cuffy was the best bowler for Spoilers, grabbing 2/27 in four overs. In reply, Spoilers raced to 205/3 in 19.3 overs to come away with the win. Suresh Baal showed his quality with an unbeaten 73. John Boopraj tried to limit the Spoilers batsmen with figures of 2/39 in four overs. Nazarites are seeded second after winning Group B and will aim for a semifinal spot against Revellers, who were third in Group A. The other quarterfinals will see Links XI (third seed) battle Rochard Road (sixth seed) and Hillpiece (fourth) will play All Apaches (fifth). The quarterfinals will end on May 31. The Brothers Premier League bowled off in March. The post Spoilers look strong as Brothers T20 League reaches quarterfinal stage appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .

data.title: Investigations ongoing – More SoE charges possible
data.description: Police say more charges are possible as a result of investigations launched against people arrested during the state of emergency (SoE). The SoE, which began on December 30 and ended on April 13, saw 50 people detained under the authority of a Preventive Detention Order. Of that number, 14 people who police said are affiliated with two particular gangs, were charged with multiple gang-related offences. Despite the release of the remaining 34, police have always maintained investigations are continuing and they can be charged at a later date. At the police media briefing on May 27, TTPS legal officer Cpl Zaheer Ali said the investigations “have progressed evidentially.” Asked for an update on the possibility of more people being charged, Ali said, “In some instances, those investigative files are engaging the legal officers in the TTPS.” “And in some instances, consultations are ongoing with the Director of Public Prosecutions, so I anticipate that in the near future and within a reasonable time, our commissioner will be able to respond as to whether in fact those cases have matured to attract prosecutions.” Ali said police have been “thinking out of the box” to address the challenges they faced in completing the investigations. “We are exploring the law and we have made some progress. When you are dealing with organised crime and gang investigations, those are complex matters. And when you are heavily dependent on witnesses to come forward, it definitely will create a challenge.” Acting Police Commissioner Junior Benjamin said police are pleased with crime statistics this year in comparison to previous years, describing it as a small win. He noted there has been a year-on-year reduction in violent crimes including murders. There were 228 murders between January 1 and May 27, 2024 compared to 153 for the same period this year. This is an even further decrease from the 242, during that same period, in 2023. “When we look at our murders we have at least a 33 per cent reduction, against that of last year. When we look at our violent crimes in 2024 we had, 1991 reports. Now in 2025 we have only 1424 reports. That is a 28 per cent reduction.” Breaking the figure down by month, Benjamin said there have been 23 murders in May compared to 52 murders in May 2024, and 49 in May 2023. He attributed the decline to the hard work of the police. “We are not just seeing a reduction in murders, but also a reduction in terms of woundings and shootings. “In 2024, we had 297, in 2025 we have 210. We are also seeing a reduction in terms of sexual offences with 338 reports in 2024, and 330 in 2025.” He said police are grateful for the “positive change,” and added Port of Spain, Tobago and North Central divisions have had the highest murder rate reduction with 68, 69 and 70 per cent, respectively. Benjamin said despite these gains, police are still not satisfied and urged the public to join them in the fight against crime to ensure any progress made, is not lost. The post Investigations ongoing – More SoE charges possible appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .

data.title: No secretary appointed yet to replace Sampson
data.description: A replacement is yet to be named for Joel Sampson as the Secretary of Community Development, Youth Development and Sport in the Tobago House of Assembly (THA). Sampson resigned from the post after being elected MP for Tobago West. He was also the electoral representative for the Crown Point/Bon Accord district. Sampson won his seat in the April 28 general election on a Tobago People’s Party (TPP) ticket, securing the constituency with a total of 6,713 votes, 109 votes more than PNM's Shamfa Cudjoe-Lewis. On May 5, Chief Secretary Farley Augustine told Newsday that a councillor or an elected assemblyman will soon be selected to replace Sampson as secretary. He said the replacement had already been identified but noted that the name will not be disclosed until all legal formalities are completed. Augustine said there will be no by-election in the Crown Point/Bon Accord district as the vacancy arose within one year of THA elections, which are constitutionally due in 2025. Newsday tried to contact Augustine for an update on the new secretary, but all calls and messages were unanswered on May 27. Contacted via WhatsApp on May 27, Deputy Chief Secretary Dr Faith Brebnor, who also holds the position of TPP deputy political leader, said, “We’ll make the announcements soon.” Newsday tried to contact Assistant Secretary of Community Development, Youth Development and Sport Wane Clarke for an update on the division, but all calls were unanswered up to press time.. The post No secretary appointed yet to replace Sampson appeared first on Trinidad and Tobago Newsday .
